newsitem.title: GREECE: PRESS DIGEST - GREEK GENERAL NEWS- JAN 17.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - GREEK GENERAL NEWS- JAN 17.

text.p: Leading stories in the Greek general press:
--German officials have accused Intracom boss Socrates Kokkalis of collaborating with East German secret police STASI in an effort to further business aims.

--Education Minister Gerasimos Arsenis yesterday proposed to Cabinet far-reaching changes to the university entrance system, proposing that the quality of secondary school education be improved by abolishing university entrance exams, in an effort to upgrade general education.
--The Simitis government does not appear to have changed its hardline stance over farmers' demands. The new round of protests is expected to be greeted with the same attitude.
--Airport employees will today begin work stoppages to last the next four days, seriously disrupting schedules at airports around the country.
--University officials have welcomed Arsenis's general proposals on education but say they will need money and infrastructure to work.
--Ships will remain anchored for a further four days, following last night's decision by striking seamen and dockworkers. Shipowners have taken the strike to court. TA NEA
--The new dialogue on education implies a massive influx of new students to institutes of higher education. Arsenis says tertiary education should be available to all those who want it.
--The archaeologist in charge of excavations at the recently-discovered cave of Euripides gives a guided tour.
--The government has drafted an "anti-blockade" plan to deal with the farmers' new round of protests.
--Also on the labour front, there were blows exchanged port-side yesterday and ships will remain anchored until Monday. --Maria Petrakis, Athens Newsroom +301 3311812-4
